snippet: Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney, did not object to rabbis’ insistence on screening molestation allegations before reporting them, and he appears to have inflated claims about a crackdown on sex abuse in ultra-Orthodox communities.
abstract: Victims' rights groups continue to express concern that Brooklyn District Attorney Charles J Hynes is not vigorously pursuing sexual abuse cases in ultra-Orthodox Jewish communities because of his deep ties to Brooklyn rabbis, many of whom view such accusations as community matters; Hynes says effort to reach out to ultra-Orthodox victims of child sexual abuse has contributed to an effective crackdown, but he appears to have inflated claims about the program's success.

byline.original: By RAY RIVERA and SHARON OTTERMAN
byline.contributor: Jo Craven McGinty, Griff Palmer and Tom Torok contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney, did not object to rabbis’ insistence on screening molestation allegations before reporting them, and he appears to have inflated claims about a crackdown on sex abuse in ultra-Orthodox communities.

headline.seo: For Ultra-Orthodox Jews in Abuse Cases, a Prosecutor Uses Different Rules
headline.main: For Ultra-Orthodox in Abuse Cases, Prosecutor Has Different Rules
headline.print_headline: For Ultra-Orthodox in Abuse Cases, Prosecutor Has Different Rules
